awd_titl_txt: EAGER: USBRCCR: Collaborative: Lightweight Policy Enforcement of Information Flows in IoT Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
As Internet of Things (IoT) systems become deployed more widely, their security is becoming a serious concern in many domains, including smart homes, autonomous cars, or industrial control systems.  Security exploits in IoT systems can lead to loss of privacy, data theft, financial losses, and even physical harm.  The proposed work will develop a novel approach to harden security of IoT systems via cross-layer defense.  The approach will be developed and evaluated in collaboration among three participating institutions in the US and Brazil.  The project aims to provide technical foundations to harden the defense against several types of security attacks in IoT systems, and the project will also create broader impact through dissemination of results and education efforts.

More technically, the proposed approach considers cross-layer defense at IoT app layer, network layer, and devices.  The central concept is flow policies: the proposed work extracts flow policies from IoT apps, and then uses these policies to enforce desired flows and to detect violations at both the device and network layers. In contrast to general-purpose applications, the flows in IoT apps are expected to be often predictable and expressive enough to capture important properties such that detected flow violations indicate real problems and not false alarms.  If policies are indeed found to be expressive enough, and checking them is lightweight in IoT systems, the approach will provide substantial benefits to improve defense of IoT systems in practice.

por.por_cntn:
As Internet of Things (IoT) systems become deployed more widely, their security is becoming a serious concern in many domains, including smart homes, autonomous cars, or industrial control systems. Security exploits in IoT systems can lead to loss of privacy, data theft, financial losses, and even physical harm.


This project developed a novel approach to harden security of IoT systems by providing mechanisms to control information flows of private user data. The approach was developed and evaluated in collaboration among three participating institutions, two from the US -- the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the University of Michigan -- and one university from Brazil -- Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPE). The project was in the USBRCCR program that supported establishing and strengthening collaborations among US and Brazilian researchers. The project additionally led to advancing techniques for runtime monitoring and security of software systems, a vulnerability study of the security of popular IoT devices, and improvements to a language used for modeling and analysis of security properties.


The grant partially supported (1) over 15 papers with US authors (including papers co-authored by Illinois and Michigan, Michigan and UFPE, and UFPE and Illinois); (2) public release of code for fine-grained flow control; and (3) training of over a dozen graduate students (including one PhD dissertation) and several undergraduate students (some of whom co-authored papers or contributed to open-source code), either directly supported by the award or collaborating on the project. Additional broader impacts were realized through the USBRCCR program: the active collaborations and visits among US and Brazilian institutions in this project offered opportunities for both students and professors to develop technical solutions and improve cross-cultural understanding beyond typical NSF projects.
